history.content:
Here is one opinion. Hell no. Stay far away from this. It's one thing to spend a few days classifying the data to understand the nature of it and to create a human benchmark (see here), but completely another to do manual tasks as an EECS  undergrad for a shot at playing around with data. I think it's honestly degrading to ask you to spend 70% of your time on labeling data. Other people might give you advice that any opportunity is a good opportunity, but my personal opinion is that you're much better off taking a class in summer session and treating a Kaggle competition like a full time job.

Edit: Same person here. I think that this is one of those things you'll just have to trust us (other students who have done internships already). It seems like a great opportunity, but in retrospect you'll realize you were being taken advantage of. I have no doubt you could potentially enjoy the experience, but please take into account the fact that you are more than fine without this internship.

Here is one opinion. Hell no. Stay far away from this. It's one thing to spend a few days classifying the data to understand the nature of it and to create a human benchmark (see here), but completely another to do manual tasks as an EECS  undergrad for a shot at playing around with data. I think it's honestly degrading to ask you to spend 70% of your time on labeling data. Other people might give you advice that any opportunity is a good opportunity, but my personal opinion is that you're much better off taking a class in summer session and treating a Kaggle competition like a full time job.

children.subject:
Not entirely sure what it means classifying image/video data, but it sounds like just busy work and nothing related to Software Engineering in AI/ML? If it's just busy work that anyone can do, and that's 70% of what you're doing, i'd say no.

I am graduating after 3 years, only interned last summer, and got lots of offers. You don't need a sophomore internship at all to get a job, you don't even need an internship your junior year as well if you code on your free time, interview prep, and possibly get referrals.

Keep trying, but you'll be way better off spending your summer bettering yourself as an engineer and person.

Thanks for your opinion and I definitely see what you're saying. I would definitely prefer a more technical position but seeing as it's pretty late in the game not so sure about that. Would love to hear what other people think/if anyone has experience with this!
Honestly you'd be better off working on a personal project or taking summer courses than doing grunt work.

history.content: I am interviewing for an internship at an AI/ML healthcare startup that is doing some pretty cool stuff, but he said that part of the time (about 70%) would be spent manually classifying image/video data for their computer algorithms, while the other time I would be able to play around with the dataset and try to apply some of the AI/ML techniques. I guess my question is, is it worth it to go for an internship where a fairly large part of it may be grunt work like this (opportunity also has no prior programming experience required). I am an EECS sophomore and am just wondering if internships like these are good just for the experience + people I will meet, or will I feel like I am wasting time? This is my first real internship so not really sure what to expect. Honest opinions please!
history.subject: is internship worth it?
